comments.body: Not sure how I feel about changing the public API on these, but maybe it's fine.

I think it's fine: they just make the function easier to call, and they're on functions that already return `undefined` or `boolean`, which implies (correctly) that they pass through `undefined` if you call them.

Do we also need to add the response types? We currently have to maintain a copy of them in VS Code: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/3d500ebd8b4a919e8631e916f417e5c68eb90d3f/extensions/typescript-language-features/src/languageFeatures/semanticTokens.ts#L275
Aren’t they in typescript/tsserver .d.ts ?
We currently only use `protocol.d.ts` with VS Code. I think this should have all the types used communicating from or to tsserver
Makes sense, added
@sandersn is the best person to judge if this is appropriate

@DanielRosenwasser Yes, you are right. Quick note: `try {} catch (/** @type {unknown} */ e) {}` - `e` is a `VariableDeclaration`, and in the current implementation, JSDoc comment is not attached to `e`. To have the opportunity to add a type declaration node has to have JSDoc, these changes related to that. Does that make sense?  If there is a better way to do this, I can change that.

No, I think this is the best way.
In fact, in normal `var` declarations, we don't currently look for jsdoc on VariableDeclarations, meaning that `x: boolean` and `y: boolean` below, instead of `string` and `number` (or error, because of the conflict).

```js
/** @type {boolean} */
var /** @type {string} */ x, /** @type {number} */ y;
```

Actually, can you add the above as a test? I wonder how much of that will Just Work after this change. It's likely that quite a bit of it will, because there's no walking up the tree required.

If it *doesn't*, that's fine; we haven't had anybody ask for it, nor have we gone looking whether it's a common pattern (my guess is No).

> Actually, can you add the above as a test? 

@sandersn I've added a test and the other tests seem to work fine.
You missed another `

Copy pasta

```suggestion
         * In the absence of `CompletionEntry["replacementSpan"]`, the editor may choose whether to use
```
This would be a break if we want it for 3.9.  Any way we can avoid it?

Easily - now that I've used it to audit our internal usages, swapping it back is pretty simple; changing it is just for safety at callsites (so we may still want it for the 4.0 branch, where we may eventually add more).
I feel like I'm missing something obvious, but shouldn't there also be a protocol change for this?
Wait, isn't this a breaking protocol change?  Don't we have to add a parallel array of flags that may or may not be provided?
I think the idea is that it would only return the new type if the client asked for it in the request. (Maybe this should be clarified in the doc comment for the property though)
Updated the doc comment to clarify this. :)
This comment was previously not a properly formed JSDoc format so it didn’t show up here. I just added an extra `*`.
I thought this had already been addressed in #29783?
I un-addressed it to make the nightlies build again.
I don't think this should be included in the declaration file. I'll open a separate issue for that
This is an internal-only change. (#24966)
Well...this is just `0` now, so it doesn't seem necessary :D

Nah. It's only zero because `SingleLine` desugars to zero because reasons (because it's the default). It still carries semantic meaning should we choose to adjust the list format again in the future, as it is a very unique list kind.
are these aliases meant to be public? I guess maybe they are required for export to services/

I wanted to make them public (like `HasJSDoc`), because knowing what nodes have a `.type` or a `.initializer` is a useful set of nodes, IMO. It can be internal, since I don't think any public functions use them?
I don't care much either way, just checking.
this is going to be a breaking change to `Session` users. previously these were optional on `ServerHost`, now they are required.
But wasnt that implicit requirement? since we use watchFile and watchDirectory anyways without checking if host has it?
we do :) ok then. we need to check the jetbrain folks that this is not going to break them
Would be nice to have #8306 so we didn't need to include this..
